questions.text: A patient experiencing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is undergoing resuscitation due to active bleeding. Laboratory tests have shown a critically low fibrinogen level. What is the recommended target fibrinogen level for patients with active bleeding during postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.explanation:
Laboratory Evaluation

Description

Routine Laboratory Tests

Tests:

  • Complete blood count (including platelet count),
  • Type and crossmatch for multiple units of red blood cells,
  • Coagulation studies (fibrinogen concentration, prothrombin time, activated partial thromboplastin time).

Note: Hemoglobin levels drop by ~1 g/dL for every 500 mL of blood loss.

Fibrinogen Measurement
  • Fibrinogen levels drop earlier than other coagulation factors and are a sensitive indicator of ongoing blood loss.
  • Normal Range:
    • 350-650 mg/dL in pregnancy.
    • Levels below 200 mg/dL are associated with severe PPH and higher morbidity/mortality.
  • Target: Recommended to maintain fibrinogen levels >200 mg/dL, ideally >300 mg/dL in active bleeding.

Viscoelastic Testing:

TEG/ROTEM 

Thromboelastography (TEG) and rotational thromboelastometry (ROTEM).

  • Function: Assess global blood hemostasis by measuring clot development, stabilization, and dissolution.
  • Usage: Effective for guiding plasma and coagulation product therapy.
  • ROTEM Findings:
    • FIBTEM A10 (Amplitude at 10 minutes) ≤17 mm is suggestive of low fibrinogen levels.
    • Fibrin-based clot strength (FIBTEM) is an early indicator of bleeding severity. FIBTEM A5 <10 mm may indicate severe PPH.

questions.text: A 28 y/o woman, G2P2, presents to the emergency on postpartum day 10 with complaints of vaginal bleeding. She reports with fever, chills, and feels lightheaded and weak. O/E, the uterus is larger than expected for her postpartum state, and there is moderate vaginal bleeding. Her hemoglobin level is 7.8 g/dL. All of the following can cause postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in this patient, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Secondary Postpartum Hemorrhage

Cause

Description

Retained Placental Fragments and Membranes (Option A)
  • Most common cause
  • They can prevent proper uterine involution and healing, leading to significant bleeding.
  • Rarely, retained products undergo necrosis and fibrin deposition, forming a placental polyp that can cause severe hemorrhage.

Infection

Tissue breakdown and delayed healing

Endometritis (Option C)
  • Inflammation of the uterine lining and delayed healing.
  • Symptoms typically include fever, uterine tenderness, and foul-smelling lochia.

Subinvolution of Placental Site
  • Uterus's failure to return to its normal size after delivery.
  • When the placental site heals slowly, it can increase the risk of secondary bleeding

Uterine artery Pseudoaneurysm (Option D)

  • A severe but rare cause of secondary PPH.
  • It occurs when a pseudoaneurysm forms in the uterine artery, leading to delayed hemorrhage.

questions.text: All of the following are recommended during postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) blood loss management EXCEPT:

options.label: C
options.text: Ensuring APTT <1.5 times the normal range

options.label: D
options.text: Routine use of recombinant activated factor VII (rFVIIa)

questions.correct_answer: D. Routine use of recombinant activated factor VII (rFVIIa)

questions.text: A 36 y/o woman, G3P2, delivered via C-section 4 hours ago and is now experiencing severe PPH unresponsive to uterine massage and uterotonics. Her vital signs show tachycardia and hypotension. The medical team opts for surgical intervention to avoid a hysterectomy. What is the principle behind performing bilateral internal iliac artery ligation to control her PPH?

options.label: A
options.text: To apply direct pressure on the bleeding site

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce distal blood flow and convert arterial pressure to venous-like pressure

options.label: C
options.text: To increase uterine contractility and reduce bleeding

options.label: D
options.text: To promote rapid healing of uterine tissues

questions.correct_answer: B. To reduce distal blood flow and convert arterial pressure to venous-like pressure

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman, G3P2, delivered a healthy baby via vaginal delivery and is now experiencing heavy atonic PPH unresponsive to uterine massage and uterotonic agents, and her vitals show an HR of 110 bpm and BP of 90/60 mmHg. Bimanual uterine tamponade is initiated, 2 Units of blood is on its way. Which surgical option is most appropriate to control this patient's PPH?
questions.explanation:
Uterine Devascularization

  • Progressive ligation of more proximal arteries to control uterine bleeding.
  • May require a hysterectomy if unsuccessful.

Bilateral Uterine Artery Ligation (Option A)

Ligation of the ascending branch of each uterine artery at the lateral border of the uterus.

Ovarian and Uterine Artery Anastomosis Ligation

Ligation of the anastomosis between ovarian and uterine arteries on each side.

Bilateral Internal Iliac Artery Ligation

Ligation of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery on one or both sides to reduce blood flow to the uterus.

Uterine Compression Sutures

Techniques involving sutures to compress the uterus and control bleeding.

B-Lynch Suture (Option B)
  • Envelops and compresses the uterus; most common technique.
  • Effective for uterine atony, simple to learn, safe
  • May increase risk of Asherman syndrome.

Hayman Technique
  • Uses two to four vertical compression sutures without hysterotomy.
  • Suitable after vaginal birth.

Pereira Technique
  • Involves transverse and longitudinal sutures around the uterus without entering the uterine cavity.
  • Requires care to avoid damaging blood vessels, ureters, and fallopian tubes; manual compression before tying sutures.

Cho Technique
  • Utilizes multiple squares or rectangles for uterine compression.

Uterine Artery Embolization (Option D)

Minimally invasive procedure using interventional radiology to block blood flow by injecting embolic material.

Hysterectomy (Option C)

It is a last resort for PPH, it may be necessary in cases where other measures have failed or when there are compelling reasons to remove the uterus. In emergency situations, a subtotal hysterectomy, where the cervix is left intact, is typically performed.

questions.text: A 32-y/o woman presents with severe PPH following a difficult delivery. Despite initial management with uterotonic agents, bleeding persists. She is stabilized and prepared for further intervention. Which of the following interventions is considered first-line surgical management for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Intrauterine Hemorrhage-Control Devices

Intrauterine hemorrhage-control devices are typically used for uterine atony unresponsive to medications and massage, often as a step before more invasive surgery.

Contraindications:

  • Allergy to any device component or packing material.
  • Retained Products: Should not replace evacuation of retained pregnancy tissue.

Intrauterine Balloon Tamponade (Option B)

Types: Multiple balloon catheters used for intrauterine tamponade.

Examples:

  • Sengstaken tube
  • Bakri, BT-cath, ebb complete
  • Foley's catheter (can hold up to 100 ml of fluids)
  • Condoms

Mechanism: Hydrostatic pressure applied inward to outward against uterine wall to reduce blood flow and facilitate clotting.

Vacuum-Induced Tamponade

Mechanism: Applies low-level intrauterine vacuum (70-90 mmHg) to evacuate blood and clot, facilitating uterine contractions.

Intrauterine Packing (Option A)

Plain Gauze/Laparotomy Sponges: Traditional packing method; Replaced by balloon tamponade due to its effectiveness.

Hemostatic Gauze: Gauze with additional hemostatic mechanisms

Compressed Mini-Sponges: Novel device.

Uterine or Hypogastric Artery Embolization (Option C)

Candidates
  • Suitable for patients with persistent, slow, excessive bleeding.
  • Hemodynamically stable and unresponsive to less invasive treatments.

Procedure
  • Performed by an interventional vascular specialist using diagnostic angiography.
  • Gelfoam is the preferred embolizing agent (temporary occlusion: 2-6 weeks).

questions.text: Which of the following medications is correctly matched with its mechanism of action and recommended dosage for managing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?

options.label: A
options.text: Carboprost - Derivative of prostaglandin F2α - 250 μg IM, repeat every 15-90 mins (up to 8 doses)

options.label: B
options.text: Misoprostol - Antifibrinolytic agent - 1 g IV administration

options.label: C
options.text: Tranexamic Acid - Synthetic prostaglandin E1 analogue - 800 mcg sublingually as a single dose

options.label: D
options.text: Carboprost - Synthetic prostaglandin E1 analogue - 600 to 1,000 mcg rectally as a single dose

questions.correct_answer: A. Carboprost - Derivative of prostaglandin F2α - 250 μg IM, repeat every 15-90 mins (up to 8 doses)
questions.explanation:
Medication

Mechanism of Action

Dosage

Efficacy and Side Effects

Carboprost

Derivative of prostaglandin F2α

250 μg IM, repeat every 15-90 mins (up to 8 doses)
  • Effective -88% success rate
  • Side effects: diarrhea, hypertension, vomiting, fever, flushing, tachycardia
  • Contraindications: asthma, pulmonary hypertension, suspected amniotic fluid embolism, and certain renal, liver, and cardiac conditions.

Misoprostol

Synthetic prostaglandin E1 analogue
  • Oral: 600 to 1,000 mcg as a single dose
  • Rectal: 600 to 1,000 mcg as a single dose.
  • Sublingual: 800 mcg as a single dose
  • Limited benefit over oxytocin or ergonovine
  • Side effects: Tachysystole, meconium passage, and possibly uterine rupture.
  • Contraindicated in women with previous cesarean birth
  • Contraindicated in confirmed or suspected ectopic or molar pregnancy

Tranexamic Acid

Antifibrinolytic agent
  • 1 g (10 mL of 100 mg/mL solution) intravenously over 10 to 20 minutes
  • Infusion Rate: Should not exceed 1 mL/minute to avoid hypotension
  • Repeat Dose: If bleeding continues after 30 minutes, a second 1 g dose can be given
  • Reduces mortality
  • Low rates of severe PPH, blood transfusion, and peripartum hysterectomy.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, G2P1, is currently in labor with suspected twin pregnancy. She has just delivered the first baby, and the medical team is considering administering methylergometrine to manage the third stage of labor. Which of the following is the most appropriate action regarding the use of methylergometrine in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer immediately after the delivery of the first baby to prevent postpartum hemorrhage.

options.label: B
options.text: Administer only after the delivery of the second baby to avoid compromising the remaining fetus.

options.label: C
options.text: Avoid administration completely due to the risk of uterine tetanic contractions affecting the second baby.

options.label: D
options.text: Administer before the delivery of the first baby to ensure active management of the third stage of labor.

questions.correct_answer: C. Avoid administration completely due to the risk of uterine tetanic contractions affecting the second baby.
questions.explanation:
Methylergometrine

Mode of Action

Directly acts on the myometrium, causing strong and frequent uterine contractions, leading to uterine spasms.

Administration

Oral Dose:

  • 0.2 mg taken 3 to 4 times daily during the puerperium.
  • Duration: Up to 7 days (maximum).

IM/IV Dose:

  • 0.2 mg administered after delivery of the anterior shoulder, placenta, or during puerperium.
  • Repeat every 2 to 4 hours if necessary.
  • IV is reserved for life-threatening situations.

Uses
  • Prophylactic: Active management of the third stage of labor to prevent excessive bleeding post-delivery.
  • Therapeutic: To control atonic uterine bleeding after delivery, abortion, or expulsion of a hydatidiform mole.

Side Effects
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Vasoconstriction causing hypertension, myocardial infarction, stroke, bronchospasm
  • Possible gangrene of toes with repeated use
  • Interference with lactation

Contraindications
  • Suspected multiple pregnancy after the delivery of the first baby
  • Organic cardiac diseases (risk of right heart overload and failure)
  • Severe pre-eclampsia/eclampsia (risk of hypertension or eclampsia)
  • Rh-negative mother (increased risk of fetomaternal microtransfusion)
  • Heart disease
  • Severe hypertensive disorders (risk of hypertension or cardiac failure)
  • Presence of sepsis
  • During labor induction or the first and second stages of labor
  • Vascular disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is receiving oxytocin infusion to manage postpartum hemorrhage. After a prolonged administration of high doses, she begins to exhibit symptoms of confusion, headache, and nausea. Laboratory tests reveal hyponatremia. What is the most likely mechanism behind this patient's hyponatremia associated with high-dose oxytocin administration?

options.label: B
options.text: Oxytocin acts as an antidiuretic hormone (ADH), causing water retention

options.label: C
options.text: Direct renal toxicity leading to hyponatremia

options.label: D
options.text: Increased sodium loss through excessive sweating due to flushing

questions.correct_answer: B. Oxytocin acts as an antidiuretic hormone (ADH), causing water retention
questions.explanation:
Oxytocin Infusion Initiation
  • Oxytocin is given before or after placental separation to reduce postpartum bleeding and hemorrhage risk.
  • Infusion rates can be increased if bleeding exceeds normal levels.

Administration
  • Intramuscular: 10 units (including directly into the myometrium).
  • Intravenous:
    • 10 to 30 units in 500 mL normal saline or 20 to 60 units in 1 L normal saline, with a bolus over 10 to 15 minutes, followed by maintenance infusion at a lower rate.
    • Maximum infusion: 40 units/hour.
    • Higher doses (e.g., up to 80 units in 500 mL over 30 minutes) are avoided to minimize fluid overload.

Side Effects
  • Common: Flushing due to peripheral vasodilation.
  • Serious: Rapid IV administration of high doses can cause hypotension, tachycardia, chest pain, cardiovascular collapse, and rarely, water retention leading to hyponatremia.

Carbetocin
  • Long-acting analog of oxytocin, used for preventing uterine atony and hemorrhage.
  • Administration: 100 mcg IV slow injection (over one minute); lower doses may also be effective.
  • Advantages: Lower risk compared to high-dose oxytocin

questions.text: What is the most common cause of maternal mortality in India?
questions.explanation:
Causes of Maternal Mortality

Causes

Percentage (%)

Hemorrhage:

  • Majorly- Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Other - Antepartum, retained placenta, ectopic pregnancies (Option A)

20-25

Infection (Option C)

15-20

Hypertension - Eclampsia, Pre eclampsia (Option B)

12-15

Unsafe Abortion (Option D)

10-13

Obstructed Labour

8

Anemia

15-20

Other indirect causes (Viral Hepatitis)

5-10

questions.text: A 32 y/o G3P2 woman underwent a vaginal delivery of a healthy newborn. She begins to show signs of PPH with the following vital signs: pulse rate 130 bpm, blood pressure 90/60 mm Hg, respiratory rate 24 breaths/min, oxygen saturation 94% on room air. She is alert and oriented but appears pale. What is the most appropriate immediate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Insert a Foley catheter to monitor urine output.

options.label: D
options.text: Start a continuous infusion of magnesium sulfate.

questions.correct_answer: B. Administer 2 liters of crystalloids rapidly.
questions.explanation:
Management Strategy

Description

Resuscitate with Crystalloid and Blood

Crystalloid:

  • Typically, isotonic crystalloids are infused to prevent hypotension and maintain urine output (>30 mL/hour).
  • Infuse up to twice the lost volume or 3.5 L for significant blood loss.
  • Monitor hematocrit, coagulation, core temperature, and electrolytes to avoid dilutional coagulopathy and imbalances. Monitor urine output.

Blood Products:

  • Early blood product replacement is advised for heavy hemorrhage to replace RBCs, platelets, and coagulation factors.
  • Aggressive transfusion: For unstable patients to minimize risks.

Fibrinogen Concentrate
  • Heat-treated, lyophilized fibrinogen powder from pooled human plasma. Each 50 mL vial contains ~1000 mg fibrinogen.
  • Administered alone or with cryoprecipitate.
  • Indications: Critically low fibrinogen levels (<100 mg/dL) when FFP and cryoprecipitate are unavailable.

Prothrombin Complex Concentrate (PCC)
  • Available in three-factor (II, IX, X) and four-factor (II, VII, IX, X) forms.
  • Indications: Urgent reversal of acquired factor deficiencies due to vitamin K antagonists.

Recombinant Factor VIIa (rFVIIa)
  • Off-label for severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • Dosage: 16.7 to 120 mcg/kg, typically starting at 40-60 mcg/kg. Repeat if there is no response.
  • Advantages: Effective in refractory bleeding; dose titration possible.

Maintain Oxygenation
  • Ensure oxygen saturation >95% with high-flow oxygen (10-15 L/min). Assess the airway and intubate if necessary.
  • Advantages: Improves oxygen-carrying capacity.
  • Considerations: Low flow rates may lead to CO2 retention and worsen conditions.

Avoid Hypothermia and Acidosis
  • Maintain normothermia (temperature ≥35.5°C) and correct acidosis if needed.
  • Advantages: Prevents coagulopathy and adverse outcomes.
  • Considerations: Use warming devices and correct pH if <7.1. Acidosis correction can improve pH without bicarbonate.

Consider Uterine or Hypogastric Artery Embolization
  • Performed by an interventional specialist; options include Gelfoam (temporary occlusion) or N-butyl cyanoacrylate (permanent).
  • Indications: Persistent bleeding in hemodynamically stable patients or those who fail less invasive treatments.

questions.text: A 32y/o woman presents with heavy vaginal bleeding shortly after delivery. The placenta is retained despite oxytocin administration. Manual removal of the placenta is indicated. Which of the following statements regarding the procedure is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Procedure should be performed without analgesia to facilitate placental detachment

options.label: B
options.text: Adequate analgesia is essential to minimize discomfort during the procedure.

options.label: C
options.text: The aseptic technique is unnecessary due to the urgency of the situation.

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate traction on the umbilical cord to expedite placental expulsion.

questions.correct_answer: B. Adequate analgesia is essential to minimize discomfort during the procedure.
questions.explanation:
Manual Removal of Placenta

Indication

Heavy bleeding persists with placental retention.

Procedure
  • Adequate analgesia and aseptic technique are essential. (Option A)
  • Insert fingertips between the uterine wall and placenta.
  • Sweep forward to detach the placenta from uterine attachment.
  • Remove trailing membranes with ring forceps or gauze-wrapped hands.

Alternative Method: Bierer forceps guided by ultrasound for retained placenta.

Antibiotic prophylaxis

Ampicillin or cefazolin prophylaxis post-procedure (WHO)

Difficulties
  • Hour-glass contraction leads to difficulty in introducing the hand.
  • Morbid adherent placenta causes difficulty in reaching the plane of placental separation, necessitating gentle removal in fragments using ovum forceps.

Complications
  • Hemorrhage due to incomplete removal
  • Shock
  • Uterine injury
  • Infection
  • Inversion (rare)
  • Subinvolution
  • Thrombophlebitis
  • Embolism

questions.text: During the active management of the third stage of labor, which intervention is recommended to prevent postpartum hemorrhage primarily due to uterine atony?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate IV administration of 20 units of undiluted oxytocin

options.label: C
options.text: Vigorous fundal massage combined with a uterotonic agent

options.label: D
options.text: Controlled cord traction with immediate removal of the placenta

questions.correct_answer: C. Vigorous fundal massage combined with a uterotonic agent

questions.text: A 28 y/o G3P2 woman at 39 weeks with a h/o previous C-Section with spontaneous labor in the labor ward has just delivered a healthy baby girl via vaginal delivery. She has been diagnosed with severe anemia (Hb 8 g/dL). The obstetric team is concerned about the risk of PPH. What is the next best step in her management to prevent PPH?

options.label: D
options.text: Administration of oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery

questions.correct_answer: D. Administration of oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery
questions.explanation:
Prevention of PPH

Antenatal Measures

Intranatal Measures
  • Maintain hemoglobin > 10 g/dL (Option A)
  • Screen high-risk patients and deliver in well-equipped hospitals
  • Conduct blood grouping for all women
  • Localize the placenta in women with previous cesarean delivery using USG/MRI (Option C)
  • Plan delivery of women with morbidly adherent placenta by a senior obstetrician with blood products ready
  • Active management of the third stage of labor
  • Continue oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery in induced/augmented labor
  • Administer oxytocin 5 IU slow IV during cesarean section (Option B)
  • Use Carbetocin (100 μg IV over 1 min.) to prevent PPH
  • Check the uterovaginal canal for trauma after a difficult labor or instrumental delivery
  • Observe for two hours post-delivery to ensure uterus contraction before transferring to the ward
  • Prefer local or epidural anesthesia over general anesthesia in forceps, ventouse, or breech delivery
  • Allow spontaneous placental separation during cesarean section to reduce blood loss
  • Examine the placenta and membranes routinely for completeness

questions.text: A 29 y/o woman gives birth via spontaneous vaginal delivery and experiences heavy bleeding. Her uterus remains soft and boggy despite massage and oxytocin. Which of the following is NOT a common cause of primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?
questions.explanation:
Causes of Primary PPH

Cause

Description

Factors Increasing Risk

Uterine Atony (Option A)

The inability of the uterus to contract effectively after delivery leads to a soft and boggy uterus and continuous bleeding from the placental site.
  • Grand multiparity
  • Overdistension of the uterus: Multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, large baby Malnutrition, and anemia
  • Antepartum hemorrhage: Placenta previa and placental abruption
  • Prolonged labour
  • Anesthesia
  • Oxytocin use.
  • Uterine malformations
  • Other factors: Obesity, h/o PPH, advanced maternal age (over 40 years), tocolytics and magnesium sulfate

Retained Tissue (Option B)

Prevents proper uterine contraction, causing primary PPH with continued bleeding and incomplete contraction.

Although more commonly associated with secondary PPH, retained placental fragments can also be a cause of primary PPH.

Trauma to the genital tract (Option C)

Cervical, vaginal, or perineal tears are a significant cause of primary PPH. This type of bleeding occurs despite a well-contracted uterus.
  • Assisted deliveries
  • Rapid labor
  • Large babies

Thrombin (Coagulopathy)

Involves disorders of blood clotting, which are a less common cause of PPH. They can be acquired or congenital.
  • Placental abruption
  • Jaundice in pregnancy
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • HELLP syndrome

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman delivers her first baby via spontaneous vaginal delivery. After placental delivery, she experiences significant vaginal bleeding, and her uterus remains soft and boggy despite active management of the third stage of labor. Which of the following is NOT recommended for managing uterine atony to prevent postpartum hemorrhage?

options.label: B
options.text: Performing controlled cord traction to deliver the placenta

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 28 weeks gestation undergoes routine antenatal blood testing. Her hemoglobin is found to be 10.4 g/dL, with MCV 85 fL and WBC count of 11.2 × 10⁹/L. She is asymptomatic. Which of the following best explains her laboratory findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Pathological anemia due to folate deficiency

options.label: D
options.text: Pancytopenia due to bone marrow suppression

questions.explanation:
Parameter

Change in Pregnancy

Clinical Notes

Total Blood Volume

↑ by ~40–50% (~1.5 L)

Plasma increase exceeds RBC mass → hemodilution

Plasma Volume

↑ more than RBC mass

Begins in 1st trimester, peaks in 2nd

RBC Count

↓ in 1st and 2nd trimester, slight ↑ in 3rd

Due to dilution; erythropoiesis increases in 3rd trimester

Hemoglobin (Hb)

↓ throughout pregnancy

Avg: 1st trimester ~11.6 g/dL, 2nd ~10.5 g/dL (nadir), 3rd ~11.0 g/dL; anemia if <11, <10.5, <11 g/dL respectively (WHO)

Hematocrit (Hct)

↓ due to plasma expansion

Mirrors Hb changes

MCV

Slight ↑ (~4 fL)

Peaks at 30–35 weeks in iron-replete women

WBC Count

↑ (median ~9.06 × 10⁹/L)

Mainly neutrophils; physiological leukocytosis

Neutrophils

↑ significantly

Progressive rise through pregnancy

Lymphocytes

↓ slightly

Minor change

Platelets

↓ mildly

Often stays just above 100 × 10⁹/L → gestational thrombocytopenia

Fibrinogen

↑ markedly

Levels may reach 400–600 mg/dL

Clotting Factors

↑ (VII, VIII, X, XII, vWF, ristocetin)

Supports clot formation for delivery

aPTT

↓ by ~4 seconds

Due to increased factor VIII

PT, TT

↔ (no significant change)

Remain within normal range

questions.text: Which of the following definitions best describes postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?

options.label: A
options.text: Blood loss exceeding 500 mL following childbirth

options.label: B
options.text: Any amount of bleeding from or into the genital tract after childbirth that negatively affects the patient's general condition

options.label: C
options.text: Cumulative blood loss of more than 1000 mL or any amount of blood loss with signs and symptoms of hypovolemia

questions.explanation:
Definition

WHO

Blood loss exceeding 500 mL following childbirth.

This quantitative measure is useful for statistical purposes but may not always reflect the clinical severity of the condition. (Option A)

Clinical Definition

Any amount of bleeding from or into the genital tract after childbirth that negatively affects the patient's general condition.

This clinical definition of PPH emphasizes the impact of blood loss on the mother's health rather than the exact volume, highlighting the importance of assessing the patient's condition, including elevated pulse rate and drop in blood pressure. (Option B)

ACOG - The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists

Cumulative blood loss of more than 1000 mL or any amount of blood loss with signs and symptoms of hypovolemia

This definition acknowledges that even smaller amounts of blood loss can be clinically significant if they cause hypovolemia. (Option C)
